summary: the primary target cell for HPAI H5N1 virus in human lung is the alveolar epithelial cell. alveolar epithelium and its adjacent lung microvascular endothelium form host barriers to the initiation of infection and dissemination of influenza H5N1 infection. HPAI H5N1 virus was a more potent inducer of cytokines (e.g. IP-10, RANTES, IL-6) in comparison to H1N1 virus in alveolar epithelial cells. these virus-induced chemokines were secreted onto both the apical and basolateral aspects of the polarized alveolar epithelium. alveolar epithelial cells cover over 80% of the alveolar surface. this large thin surface makes them extremely susceptible to injury from inhaled pathogens. there is no information of the effect of cell polarity on H5N1 virus replication or on virus-induced host responses. both influenza H1N1 and H5N1 viruses efficiently infect alveolar epithelial cells from both apical and basolateral surface of the epithelium. both viruses were preferentially released at the apical surface of the alveolar epithelium. the cell population was purified by a combination of differentiated cell attachment. the cells were maintained in a humidified atmosphere (5% CO2, 37°C) under liquid-covered conditions. a concomitant increase in transepithelial electrical resistance was measured using an epithelial tissue voltohmmeter (EVOM) culture and polarization of lung microvascular endothelial cell Primary human lung microvascular endothelial cells (HLMVE) were purchased from Lonza Walkersville, Inc. alveolar lumen fluid which contains high concentrations of virus. alveolar basement membrane with denuded alveolar epithelial cell will accelerate epithelial proliferation until the epithelial layer influenza H5N1 virus infected type I-like alveolar epithelial cell but not in influenza H1N1 virus infected cell. the basolateral release of chemotactic IP-10 from the influenza virus infected type I-like alveolar epithelial cells recruit lymphocytes from the capillary circulation into alveoli. cytokine secreting macrophages accumulate within the alveoli. further augmentation of the cytokine and
